title: Nicasius le Febure
text:
Nicasius le Febure, a.k.a. Nicolas le Febure or Nicasius le Fevre or Nicolas le Fèvre (1615 - 1669), was a French <a href="chemist">chemist</a> and <a href="alchemy">alchemist</a> who was appointed to positions by both <a href="French%20royalty">French</a> and <a href="List%20of%20English%20monarchs">English</a> royalty.
Early life.
Le Febure was born and educated in <a href="Sedan%2C%20Ardennes">Sedan</a>, going to the <a href="Academy%20of%20Sedan">Academy</a> there.
Work.
Vallot, first <a href="physician">physician</a> to <a href="Louis%20XIV">Louis XIV</a>, appointed him demonstrator of chemistry at the <a href="Jardin%20des%20Plantes">Jardin du Roi</a>, <a href="Paris">Paris</a>; Diarist <a href="John%20Evelyn">John Evelyn</a> is recorded as having attended a course of his lectures there in February 1647. In 1660 he was appointed Professor of Chemistry to <a href="Charles%20II%20of%20England">Charles II of England</a> in 1660, <a href="Apothecary">Apothecary</a> in Ordinary to the Royal Family in 1660 and Manager of the laboratory at <a href="St%20James%27s%20Palace">St James's Palace</a>, <a href="London">London</a>.
Personal life.
It is believed he became a naturalised <a href="British%20nationality%20law">English citizen</a> in 1662. He was elected a <a href="Fellow%20of%20the%20Royal%20Society">Fellow of the Royal Society</a> (FRS) on 20 May 1663.
Death.
Febure died in the <a href="Parish">Parish</a> of <a href="St.%20Martin-in-the-Fields">St. Martin-in-the-Fields</a>, London, in the spring of 1669. There exists an engraved portrait of him.
